Award.AwardTitle: Phylogeny, biogeography, and diversification in Pedicularis (Orobanchaceae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The disproportionate abundance of species in mountains is a striking and mysterious pattern in global biodiversity. This project will unravel the evolutionary history of one of the largest genera of flowering plants, the louseworts, whose 770 species are found in mountain ranges across the Northern Hemisphere, but are especially rich in the Hengduan Mountains of China, the Altai-Tienshan of Russia, and the Himalayas. Phylogenetic relationships of a global sample of species will be reconstructed using DNA sequences. This "family tree" will then be used as an historical framework to test hypotheses about evolution and biogeography using additional data. For example, louseworts exhibit spectacular diversity in their flowers, but are pollinated only by bumblebees. Does competition between co-occurring louseworts for pollinator services cause evolutionary divergence in flower form and accelerate the splitting of ancestral species into distinct descendants? Other questions pertain to geographic origins, such as: is the Hengduan region an evolutionary "cradle" that favors new species formation, or is it a "museum" that harbors immigrants from other regions? Finally, the phylogenetic tree will be used to construct a natural classification for the lousewort genus, with taxonomic names reflecting lineages with common ancestry.

This project will reconstruct a large, conspicuous, and enigmatic branch of flowering plants on the tree of life, and reveal historical patterns and evolutionary processes that have shaped the diversity and distributions of plant species across the Northern Hemisphere since the Miocene. Understanding these evolutionary dynamics is critical to conservation planning, e.g., to put future climate change in an historical context. The mountains where louseworts occur are particularly vulnerable to climate change, raising the imperative to document these species and their evolutionary heritage. The research will also shed light on the evolution of floral form and function, and its contribution to the tempo and mode by which plant species coexist and proliferate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project investigated the evolutionary history of one of the largest genera of flowering plants: Pedicularis (lousewort, wood betony). Its 770 species of mostly perennial herbs are found in mountains and other cool habitats of the Northern Hemisphere, but a majority - about 400 species - are endemic to the Hengduan Mountains of China, a striking concentration of diversity in a relatively young region (the mountains were uplifted less than 8 million years ago). In that biodiversity hotspot, species of Pedicularis exhibit spectacular variety in their flowers (color, shape, etc.), yet are pollinated by the same bumblebees. The genus thus presents ecological and evolutionary enigmas: Why are there so many Hengduan species?Why are their flowers so different? What role did uplift of the mountains play in their evolution and diversification?

Using data from extensive fieldwork, study of museum specimens, DNA sequences, geographic locality records, and other sources, the project advanced answers to these questions. The most comprehensive phylogeny (evolutionary tree) of the genus to date was estimated, revealing substantial incongruence with previous traditional classifications based on morphological characters. Species in the Hengduan Mountains represent an evolutionary radiation that predated the uplift of those mountains, and likely occurred in the Himalayas as they were being uplifted about 20 million years ago. Subsequently, the Himalayas and Hengduan regions acted as a source of species that colonized and radiated in other mountains throughout the Northern Hemisphere, and the Arctic, via multiple independent instances of dispersal.

In the course of the project, a new statistical method was developed for studying the tempo and mode by which species in a given geographic region accumulate through time. Applying the method to several other groups of plants common in the Hengduan flora revealed a striking general pattern of faster species formation as the mountains were uplifted over the past 8 million years, compared to the older Himalayas. These results expand our understanding of why the Henguan region is presently a biodiversity hotspot, and more generally, why mountains tend to be rich in species.

The project was a highly collaborative international effort that involved colleagues in Germany, the United Kingdom, India, China, Japan, Bhutan, Russia, and Ukraine. It trained two undergraduate students, one graduate student, one postdoctoral scholar (from China), and two early-career scientists (from Ukraine and Bhutan). Results were published in peer-reviewed journal articles and presented at conferences and invited seminars. In addition, the research was incorporated into public exhibits and education/outreach activities at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, undergraduate teaching at the University of Chicago, and a phylogenetics workshop at the National Institute of Ecology in South Korea.
